"A pleasant, joyful ride all the way up to the MÃƒÂ¼n, they said. A great and scientifically rewarding experience, they said", Wurt Kerman uttered as the g-forces squeezed him into the seat again. For a whole minute the hand of accelerometer stayed in the red zone as if it was its rightful place, and then, suddenly, the bone-crashing vibration of the solid rocket engine stopped, replaced by the weightlessness which made pieces of yesterday's meal rotate and tumble in his stomach.

"Flight control, this is Unity-5, please confirm escape velocity, preparing to jettison direct ascent stage, over."

"Unity-5, this is Control, escape velocity confirmed. Ascend stage separation in two minutes 30 seconds, over."

Aldred Kerman, the shipÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s captain, turned off the transmitter, set up the counter and began reading the check-list. Wurt, once again feeling his stomach's protests against rapid changes in acceleration, and quiet and calm Gimbal, the youngest of them, started to rotate dials and press buttons, answering captainÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s commands.

It went like this:

Switch to on-board power? - Done.

Main computer? - Turned on.

Ascent stage ASAS & on-board computer? Ã¢â‚¬â€œ Disconnected. Separation program entered.

Attitude control? Ã¢â‚¬â€œ Set to automatic. RCS slaved to computer control.

Two rolls of toilet paper, three big tomatoes, a bottle of milk... Ã¢â‚¬â€œ WHAT??! Ã¢â‚¬â€œ Oh, sorry, that was my wifeÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s shopping listÃ¢â‚¬Â¦errÃ¢â‚¬Â¦

Main thrusters? Ã¢â‚¬â€œ Ready to ignite.

Wurt did all this almost automatically, just repeating patterns heÃ¢â‚¬â„¢d learned during his year-long training period, which consisted mostly of drinking beer on the beach near the Space Centre. If youÃ¢â‚¬â„¢re good enough, they said, youÃ¢â‚¬â„¢ll get the hang of it the moment you see it.

Sometimes he thought he wasn't.

We donÃ¢â‚¬â„¢t have, you know, rear view mirrorsÃ¢â‚¬Â Ã¢â‚¬â€œ Ã¢â‚¬Å“Thrusters didn't fire, cap, thereÃ¢â‚¬â„¢re no problems with lander whatsoever. Yet.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Ã¢â‚¬Å“Ok, err, Control? We appear to have a liÃ¢â‚¬â„¢l problem with our ascend stage. Please confirm separation, over.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Ã¢â‚¬Å“This is Flight Control to Unity-5, say again?Ã¢â‚¬Â

Ã¢â‚¬Å“Unity-5, this is Control, we now appear to have a fix on your position. Ascend stage separation not confirmed, repeat, NOT confirmed, over.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Ã¢â‚¬Å“Control, this is Unity-5, we sent Wurt on the EVA, and he should check separation visually. WeÃ¢â‚¬â„¢ll route his comms via main channel, over.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Ã¢â‚¬Å“This is Wurt Kerman to Control, do you copy?Ã¢â‚¬Â

Ã¢â‚¬Å“This is Control, loud and clear. WhatÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s the status of ascend stage?Ã¢â‚¬Â

Ã¢â‚¬Å“ItÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s still attached to the lander, though all electrical connections were severed. Trying to de-attach it manually gives no results.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Ã¢â‚¬Å“This is Control, Chief Mission Engineer speaking. Wurt Kerman, our tech advisors advise returning to your ship. Chances of surviving impact inside the spacecraft are 4,867*10-8 % bigger than in your spacesuit.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Ã¢â‚¬Å“Unity-5 speaking, why donÃ¢â‚¬â„¢t your techies do something useful for a change? Like, calculate whether we have enough delta-V to land on the MÃƒÂ¼n?Ã¢â‚¬Â

Their ship was gliding silently through the cold vastness of space at the breathtaking speed of 3680 with something meters per second. The huge solid rocket stage that allowed them to obtain such tremendous speed was just a dead weight now, hanging helplessly on the mess of wires and metal shreds connecting it to the lander. Retro-rockets, responsible for the ascend stage separation, were empty and silent now. MÃƒÂ¼nÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s cratered surface was getting closer with each second, bringing imminent death to everyone aboard.

Ã¢â‚¬Å“Unity-5, Control here, we advise firing the side-mounted engines. It may finally disconnect the ascend stage, and also by going upwards youÃ¢â‚¬â„¢ll avoid collision with the MÃƒÂ¼nÃ¢â‚¬Â

Now, letÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s talk about directions. Jebediah Kerman, the first kerbal ever to go into space, defined Ã¢â‚¬Å“downÃ¢â‚¬Â as the direction his feet dangled over the edge of his bed in the morning. WeÃ¢â‚¬â„¢ll stick to that definition, not only because it provides us with a useful frame of reference, but also because it clearly shows that in space Ã¢â‚¬Å“downÃ¢â‚¬Â is just a general direction your toes are pointing at. While this is pretty clear for every kerbal whoÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s been there, it still remains somewhat of a mystery to those who work on the ground. ItÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s just another example of how the special case hinders the understanding of a general theory.

Being said, it explains the reaction our brave kerbonauts had from their discourse with the Flight Control crew.

Ã¢â‚¬Å“Unity-5 to the flight control, DEFINE Ã¢â‚¬Å“UPÃ¢â‚¬Â YOU IDIOT!!!!! And get someone useful on the line, for GodÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s sake! WeÃ¢â‚¬â„¢re in emergency situation here!Ã¢â‚¬Â

Then it became very, very quiet. And then another shout ripped the silence apart.

Ã¢â‚¬Å“WE ARE ALL GONNA DIE!!!! ME NO DIE, ME NO DIE!!!!!Ã¢â‚¬Â

Ã¢â‚¬Å“Gimbal, shut up! We wonÃ¢â‚¬â„¢t die today! We wonÃ¢â‚¬â„¢t crush into the MÃƒÂ¼n!Ã¢â‚¬Â

A new voice, sounding worried, entered the conversation.

Ã¢â‚¬Å“Unity-5, this is Crew Health Monitoring, we detect excessive sweating in the crewmember Wurt. Could you please tell him to sweat less?Ã¢â‚¬Â

Ã¢â‚¬Å“Why donÃ¢â‚¬â„¢t you check crewmember GimbalÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s EKG instead?Ã¢â‚¬Â

Ã¢â‚¬Å“ItÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s not very interesting, going flat all the timeÃ¢â‚¬Â¦wait! Is he dead already? This is the most remarkableÃ¢â‚¬Â¦ Ã¢â‚¬Â

Ã¢â‚¬Å“AAAAHHHH! IÃ¢â‚¬â„¢m NOT dead!!!Ã¢â‚¬Â

Ã¢â‚¬Å“Health Monitoring, did you hear that? That was GimbalÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s cry.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Ã¢â‚¬Å“Oh, come on! Your cheap tricks canÃ¢â‚¬â„¢t beat science! ErrÃ¢â‚¬Â¦.Captain, why your EKG is also flat?Ã¢â‚¬Â

Wurt closed the channel. It became silent again, except for GimbalÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s sobbing and unpleasant, mechanical noise of life support system rushing oxygen into the crowded cabin.

Physicists believe gravity to be one of the weakest forces in the Universe. Apparently, they've never been stuck in the rocket that ran out of fuel while trying to land on the MÃƒÂ¼nÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s surface. Even if they did, they never lived long enough to initiate that much-needed change of paradigm in the modern academia.

When Wurt almost did all delta-V calculations himself, Flight Control called again.

Ã¢â‚¬Å“Err, Flight Control speaking, guys, we've made our calculations, and you actually have just enough fuel to land on the MÃƒÂ¼n even with the ascend stage still attached. YouÃ¢â‚¬â„¢ll heat the MÃƒÂ¼n a bit hard, at 25 meters per second, but IÃ¢â‚¬â„¢m pretty sure the capsule will survive. You wonÃ¢â‚¬â„¢t have much fuel for return trip anyway, so youÃ¢â‚¬â„¢ll have to wait for the rescue mission.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Ã¢â‚¬Å“Unity-5 to Control, are you nuts? We know these Ã¢â‚¬Å“rescue missionsÃ¢â‚¬Â of yours. Bill Kerman lived in those caves on Duna for three years! And those guys on Laythe, theyÃ¢â‚¬â„¢re still growing chlorella, what is it, sixth year theyÃ¢â‚¬â„¢re stranded there or what?Ã¢â‚¬Â

Ã¢â‚¬Å“Err, Unity-5, wait a second, it seems we haAAAH!Ã¢â‚¬Â

They've heard some noises, and then a new voice, fresh and confident, entered the conversation.

Ã¢â‚¬Å“Unity-5, this is Flight Control, Jebediah Kerman speaking.Ã¢â‚¬Â

AldredÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s expression changed to that of silent, deathly horror, as if Space Kraken was staring him in the face. Gimbal started his sobbing again.

Ã¢â‚¬Å“LetÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s get rid of this ascend stage, guys!Ã¢â‚¬Â

Having multiple stages is important for almost any spacecraft. When Konstantin Kerman, the grand-grand-father of modern space exploration and rocket design, came up with the idea, he was laughed at. A lot. People of his generation imagined spaceships as huge chunks of metal, all shiny and pointy, with nice aerodynamic fins, going up using one tremendous explosion they called Ã¢â‚¬Å“a blast-offÃ¢â‚¬Â. But then the idea of riding up a continuous explosion and throwing away the dead weight to get even more explosions became much more attractive. Spandex spacesuits became obsolete approximately at the same time, opening the way to the true space exploration.

Sometimes (fairly often, actually) incorrect staging or even simply having more than one stage resulted in huge problems both for the crew and the Flight Control. Jebediah Kerman knew it perfectly well. He also knew all the solutions.

Ã¢â‚¬Å“Captain, do you see this shiny blue-brown ball ahead of you?Ã¢â‚¬Â

JebÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s voice trailed off, but a second later he regained his composure.

Ã¢â‚¬Å“Ok, never mind. Just strap yourself into the seat, disengage computer control, and set RCS to manual. WeÃ¢â‚¬â„¢ll shake this stage off using centrifugal forces.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Ã¢â‚¬Å“Now turn the ship all the way down and keep on turning.Ã¢â‚¬Â

His other hand reached for the ASAS button and pressed it hard. Acceleration pushed him into the seat, and GimbalÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s foot hit him in the face. The last thing he heard was a rasping sound of something breaking off.

When he regained consciousness the ship was slowly tumbling around. Engines were silent (he or the captain must have turned them off), and computer control was disengaged. In the side window he saw the face of the MÃƒÂ¼n, now dangerously close.

Ã¢â‚¬Å“How long have I been off?Ã¢â‚¬Â

Ã¢â‚¬Å“Unity-5, this is Control, please respond!Ã¢â‚¬Â

Ã¢â‚¬Å“Oh. Yeah. Control, this is Unity-5, whatÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s going on?Ã¢â‚¬Â

Ã¢â‚¬Å“Unity-5! Bastards, were have you been? I've missed my dinner because of you! ErrÃ¢â‚¬Â¦you shook off the ascend stage. Now Ã¢â‚¬â€œ do you see this glowing blue-brown ball?Ã¢â‚¬Â

Ã¢â‚¬Å“Yes, itÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s mostly brown now. What is it for?Ã¢â‚¬Â

Jeb sighed.

Several hours later, Unity-5 was going around the MÃƒÂ¼n. Wurt, with a black eye and a visible footprint of GimbalÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s boots on the forehead, almost uninjured Aldred and beaten to Hell Gimbal were looking out through the window, seeing mountains and plains below. When the huge, green-blue Kerbin showed on the mÃƒÂ¼nar horizon, the first message to come was from the Space ProgramÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s financial department.

Ã¢â‚¬Å“Unity-5, this is Mitt Kerman, space program financial director, youÃ¢â‚¬â„¢ll be fined for using your spacecraft to circumnavigate the MÃƒÂ¼n instead of landing on it, over.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Aah, not this idiot again, thought Gimbal.

Go to Hell, thought Aldred.

IÃ¢â‚¬â„¢ll retire anyway, thought Wurt.
